Award.AwardTitle: Peg + Cat: Developing Preschoolers' Early Math Skills

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
As part of its overall strategy to enhance learning in informal environments, the Advancing Informal STEM Learning (AISL) program funds innovative resources for use in a variety of settings. This project will develop and research an integrated children's media and early childhood educator professional development strategy to prepare preschoolers with social-emotional skills that provide a foundation for later math learning success. The social-emotional skills include persistence, risk-taking, regulating anxieties, and collaborating to solve problems. Media components include Peg+Cat television episodes, videos, games and apps distributed through PBS broadcast and online. The integrated professional development model is designed to impact these educators' understanding of math and develop their skills for fostering in children a positive math mindset. Additional resources include a new Peg+Cat summer day camp at the Carnegie Science Center in Pittsburgh. The project partners include a media company, The Fred Rogers Company; researchers at the University of Pittsburgh and St. Vincent College; and the evaluator, Rockman et al. This project is unique in its focus on integrating social-emotional skills with early math learning and educator skill development. It will fill an important niche in the research literature and has the potential to impact media practice which is undergoing significant change as new digital tools and technologies become available for learning.

Both standardized and researcher-developed measures will be used to assess learning outcomes, including early childhood educators' attitudes and quality of instruction, as well as children's interest and engagement in math. The research design includes iterative data collection to inform the development and refinement of the professional learning for teachers. The mixed methods approach will include classroom observations, interviews and focus groups with educators, and parent questionnaires. Key questions include: does exposure to Peg+Cat positively relate to children's use of social-emotional skills during math learning activities? Does educators' exposure to the professional development training improve their attitudes and abilities to infuse math instruction with social-emotional skills? Does having an educator who received Peg+Cat training impact children's engagement and interest in math?

POR.DRECONTENT:
Promoting mathematical interest, engagement, and learning in the early years is critical to future academic success. Early exposure to STEM, including math, supports children?s overall academic growth, cultivates early critical thinking and reasoning skills, and enhances later interest in STEM study and careers (National Research Council, 2011). Children?s early knowledge of math strongly predicts their later success in math (Clements and Sarama, 2009) and reading (Duncan, Dowsett, Claessens, et al., 2007). Furthermore, social-emotional learning (SEL) is inextricably intertwined with learning math. Many teaching strategies that increase student motivation also positively influence academic achievement While learning math, children benefit from support in learning to self-regulate, find help, and overcome their fear of failure, frustration, and embarrassment at mistakes (Bobis, J., Anderson, J., Martin, A. and Way, J., 2011).

Research also connects early exposure to age-appropriate TV programs designed around educational curricula with cognitive and academic enhancement (Kirkorian, Wartella, & Anderson, 2008). Positive impacts have been found for children?s development of academic and social skills, even when controlling for socioeconomic status, race, and gender (Fisch, 2007). Researchers and practitioners both suggest a need for a new model of professional development (PD) that fosters communities of practice, focuses on improving adult-child interactions, and helps teachers infuse media and SEL into their pedagogy.

Project Overview

This three-year project, funded by the National Science Foundation, focused on the development of preschool children's SEL in relation to math engagement through four primary goals. The first goal was to advance young children?s math engagement through the production of 25 episodes of Peg + Cat, an animated, math-based PBS television series for preschool children, and ancillary games and digital storybooks. Second, this project developed and tested a community of practice PD model through partnerships with local childcare centers and independent preschools. PD took place over the course of seven months and focused on a) responsive teacher-child interactions and SEL essential for sustained engagement in math and b) helping teachers infuse their math instruction with meaningful use of media content. Third, a science center summer camp model was developed as a vehicle for math engagement and learning. This camp for four and five year-olds integrated math and media engagement with hands-on activities for young children. Finally, this project intended to advance evidence-based understandings of the relations among media and technology, responsive teacher-child interactions, children?s SEL, and engagement and interest in math.

Methods and Results

This project included a randomized controlled trial with 90 preschool teachers and a randomly selected set of their children and parents. The intervention group experienced Peg + Cat media and technology PD and Simple Interactions PD, which focused on fostering social-emotionally rich interactions during instruction. Researchers collected videotapes of classroom interactions, teacher interviews, and questionnaires for teachers and parents. Primary findings suggest that social-emotional skills used during math (math persistence and math help seeking) were positively and significantly related to children?s engagement in math. Also, teachers? understanding of the way social-emotional skills come into play to help children engage in math increased as PD focused more on this topic. Teachers in the treatment group had interactions with children that were significantly more social-emotionally rich than their counterparts in the control condition. This finding may suggest a promising avenue for using teacher interactions to increase children?s engagement in math.

Evaluation explored how 15 early childhood educators and 30 preschool parents used Peg + Cat digital media resources to address math and social-emotional skills. Methods included usage forms, surveys, and interviews. While teachers explored math concepts with all of the digital media, online games were better for supporting conversations around working together and taking turns, while digital storybooks supported a wider range of social-emotional topics. Parents felt that online games were better at impacting their children?s math understanding, while digital storybooks were best at addressing social-emotional skills. Explicitly prompting parents to look for social-emotional content in the digital media was effective.

Conclusions and Implications

This project focused on supporting preschool children's SEL in relation to math engagement. We tested a PD model for early educators that combined learning around math and media engagement with SEL. Our findings have many implications for the early childhood education field, including: (1) teachers may not initially have a deep understanding of the role of SEL for engaging children in math, but with focused PD using the Simple Interactions approach, it is possible to increase this understanding; (2) PD can help increase the richness of social-emotional interactions during math, specifically math help-seeking and persistence; and (3) PD focused on math and SEL can increase children?s engagement in math. These findings show the importance of teacher PD for promoting SEL in efforts to increase children?s engage with math. Future research and practice might target teachers? understanding and emphasis on these skills.
